Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: Stakeholders expect a working prototype soon to secure internal approval
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story: I stared at the blinking cursor on my laptop, the prototype’s code only half-finished. My phone buzzed with another message from the project manager: “We need the demo ready by tomorrow. Stakeholders are anxious.” I could almost feel the weight of their expectations pressing down on me—if I didn’t deliver, the project might not get the green light. But as I glanced at the clock, my heart tightened. In just a few hours, the temple would fill with hundreds of worshippers for the most significant religious holiday of the year. As their priest, I was expected to lead the prayers, offer guidance, and be fully present for the community. They counted on me for spiritual comfort, especially on this day. I felt torn, my mind racing between lines of code and lines of scripture. Both roles demanded my full attention, both were urgent, and both mattered deeply to people who trusted me. My hands trembled as I tried to focus, but the conflict inside me only grew sharper with every passing minute.
